Class ImageProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • ImageProcessor

  • public class ImageProcessor
extends java.lang.Object
    ImageProcessor allows the user to display and edit a greyscale image in a number of ways. The program represents the image as a 2D array of integers, which must all be between 0 (black) and 255 (white). The class includes three methods (already written for you) that will - read a png or jpeg image file and store a 2D array of greyscale values into the image field. - render (display) the 2D array of greyscale values in the image field on the graphics pane - write the 2D array of greyscale values in the image field to a png file. You are to complete the methods to modify an image: - darken the image - increase the contrast - Rotate the image 180 degrees and 90 degrees - flip the image horizontally or vertically. - merge another image with the current image

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void contrastImage()
      CORE: Increase the contrast of the image - make all lighter pixels in the image (above 128) even lighter (by 20%) and make all darker pixels even darker (by 20%) For example, a pixel value of 158 is 30 levels above 128.
      void darkenImage()
      CORE: Make all pixels in the image darker by 20 greylevels.
      void doMouse(java.lang.String a, double x, double y) 
      void expandImage()
      CHALLENGE: Expand the top left quarter of the image to fill the whole image each pixel in the top left quarter will be copied to four pixels in the new image.
      void flipImageHorizontally()
      CORE: Flip the image horizontally exchange the values on the left half of the image with the corresponding values on the right half
      void flipImageVertically()
      CORE: Flip the image vertically exchange the values on the top half of the image with the corresponding values on the bottom half

      Display the image on the screen with each pixel as a square of size pixelSize.
      void rotateImage180()
      COMPLETION: Rotate the image 180 degrees Each cell is swapped with the corresponding cell on the other side of the center of the images.
      void rotateImage90()
      COMPLETION: Rotate the image 90 degrees anticlockwise Note, the resulting image will have different dimensions: the width of the new image will be the height of the old image.

    • Method Detail

      • contrastImage

        public void contrastImage()
        CORE: Increase the contrast of the image - make all lighter pixels in the image (above 128) even lighter (by 20%) and make all darker pixels even darker (by 20%) For example, a pixel value of 158 is 30 levels above 128. It should be lightened by 20% of 30 (= 6) to 164. A pixel value of 48 is 80 levels below 128. It should be darkened by 20% of 80 (= 16) to 32.

      • darkenImage

        public void darkenImage()
        CORE: Make all pixels in the image darker by 20 greylevels. but make sure that you never go below 0

      • doMouse

        public void doMouse(java.lang.String a,
                    double x,
                    double y)

      • expandImage

        public void expandImage()
        CHALLENGE: Expand the top left quarter of the image to fill the whole image each pixel in the top left quarter will be copied to four pixels in the new image. Be careful not to try to access elements past the edge of the array! Hint: It is actually easier to work backwards from the bottom right corner.

      • flipImageHorizontally

        public void flipImageHorizontally()
        CORE: Flip the image horizontally exchange the values on the left half of the image with the corresponding values on the right half

      • flipImageVertically

        public void flipImageVertically()
        CORE: Flip the image vertically exchange the values on the top half of the image with the corresponding values on the bottom half

      • lightenImage

        public void lightenImage()

      • loadAnImage

        public int[][] loadAnImage(java.lang.String imageName)
        Get and return an image as a two-dimensional grey-scale image (from 0-255). This method will cause the image to be returned as a grey-scale image, regardless of the original colouration.

      • loadImage

        public void loadImage()
        Ask user for an image file, and load it into the current image

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] arguments)

      • mergeImage

        public void mergeImage()
        CHALLENGE: Merge two images Ask the user to select another image file, and load it into another array. Work out the rows and columns shared by the images For each pixel value in the shared region, replace the current pixel value by the average of the pixel value in current image and the corresponding pixel value in the other image.

      • redisplayImage

        public void redisplayImage()
        Display the image on the screen with each pixel as a square of size pixelSize. To speed it up, all the possible colours from 0 - 255 have been precalculated.

      • rotateImage180

        public void rotateImage180()
        COMPLETION: Rotate the image 180 degrees Each cell is swapped with the corresponding cell on the other side of the center of the images. It is easier to make a new array, the same size as image, then copy each pixel in image to the right place in the new array and then assign the new array to the image field.

      • rotateImage90

        public void rotateImage90()
        COMPLETION: Rotate the image 90 degrees anticlockwise Note, the resulting image will have different dimensions: the width of the new image will be the height of the old image. the height of the new image will be the width of the old image. You will need to make a new image array of the new dimensions, fill it with the correct pixel values from the original array, and then set the image field to contain the new image.

      • saveImage

        public void saveImage()
        Write the current greyscale image to the specified filename

      • setPos

        public void setPos(double x,
                   double y)
        Set the selected Row and Col to the pixel on the mouse position x, y

      • setupGui

        public void setupGui()
